title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #395**

For unit complex vectors, is P(|ε₁z₁ + ... + εₙzₙ| ≤ √2) ≥ c/n?

**Status:** SOLVED (HJNS 2024)

The answer is YES, and the 1/n rate is optimal.

title: Unit Vector
content:
**isUnitVector z:**

∀i: |zᵢ| = 1.

The vectors lie on the complex unit circle.

title: Sign Vector
content:
**isSignVector ε:**

∀i: εᵢ ∈ {-1, 1}.

These are the random choices (uniformly distributed).

title: Signed Sum
content:
**signedSum z ε:**

ε₁z₁ + ... + εₙzₙ.

The sum of unit vectors with random signs.

title: Signed Sum Absolute Value
content:
**signedSumAbs z ε:**

|ε₁z₁ + ... + εₙzₙ|.

The magnitude of the random walk endpoint.

title: Count Small Sums
content:
**countSmallSums z:**

The number of sign vectors ε such that |signedSum z ε| ≤ √2.

Out of 2^n total sign choices.

title: Probability
content:
**probSmallSum z:**

P(|signedSum| ≤ √2) = countSmallSums / 2^n.

The main quantity of interest.

title: Original Question (FALSE)
content:
**erdos_original_question:**

Is P(|sum| ≤ 1) ≥ c/n for unit vectors?

This was Erdős's original question, but it's FALSE.

title: Counterexample
content:
**carnielli_carolino_counterexample, counterexample_always_large:**

Take z₁ = 1, zₖ = i for k ≥ 2 (n even).

Every signed sum has |sum| ≥ √2.

So P(|sum| ≤ 1) = 0.
mathContext: This disproves the original threshold-1 question.

title: Original is False
content:
**erdos_original_is_false:**

The original question (threshold 1) is FALSE.

This led to the revised question with threshold √2.

title: Revised Question (TRUE)
content:
**erdos_395_question:**

Is P(|sum| ≤ √2) ≥ c/n for unit vectors?

This is the correct formulation, and the answer is YES.

title: HJNS 2024 Theorem
content:
**hjns_2024:**

∃c > 0: ∀n, ∀ unit vectors z₁,...,zₙ:

P(|ε₁z₁ + ... + εₙzₙ| ≤ √2) ≥ c/n.

This is the main result resolving Erdős #395.

title: Problem Solved
content:
**erdos_395_solved:**

The revised question is TRUE.

Follows directly from hjns_2024.

title: Extremal Example
content:
**extremal_example, extremal_example_tight:**

zₖ = 1 for k ≤ n/2, zₖ = i otherwise.

This achieves probability exactly Θ(1/n).

Shows the 1/n rate is optimal.
mathContext: Half real, half imaginary is the worst case.

title: Optimality
content:
**bound_is_optimal:**

The 1/n rate cannot be improved to 1/n^α for any α < 1.

The extremal example proves this.

title: Classical Littlewood-Offord
content:
**littlewood_offord_classical:**

At most ~1/√n fraction of sign choices hit any fixed point.

This is an UPPER bound (anticoncentration).

title: Reverse Direction
content:
**reverse_direction:**

At LEAST Ω(1/n) fraction hit the ball of radius √2 around 0.

This is a LOWER bound - the 'reverse' direction.

title: Why √2
content:
**why_sqrt_2:**

The counterexample shows: for z₁=1, zₖ=i (k≥2), |sum| ≥ √2 always.

So threshold < √2 can have probability 0.

√2 is the critical threshold.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_395_summary:**

∃c > 0: P(|signedSum| ≤ √2) ≥ c/n for all unit vectors.

This is the main result of HJNS 2024.

title: Problem Resolved
content:
**erdos_395_resolved:**

Erdős Problem #395 was completely resolved by HJNS in 2024.
